title: Synthetic Recap
body:
INDIANAPOLIS — In the record books, it will go down as a decisive 109-91 victory for the Indiana Pacers over the New Jersey Nets. In the annals of basketball history, it will be remembered as the night Reggie Miller authored a singular, breathtaking masterpiece.

From the opening tip, Miller was a man possessed, a flurry of motion and lethal precision that the Nets had no answer for. He didn't just score; he performed a surgical dissection of the New Jersey defense, a 56-point symphony of three-point barrages, cunning back-cuts, and unerring free throws. The Continental Airlines Arena crowd, accustomed to his heroics, was transported, witnessing one of the greatest individual scoring outbursts the game has ever seen.

Miller’s historic night was a study in offensive perfection. He was ruthlessly efficient, connecting on 16 of 29 shots from the field. But it was from beyond the arc where he truly built his legend, draining an astounding 9 of 13 three-point attempts. He was flawless from the charity stripe, a perfect 15-for-15, each swish adding another brushstroke to his monumental canvas.

While teammate Rik Smits provided a solid 18-point foundation, this was unequivocally the Reggie Miller Show. The Nets, led by 22 points from Kendall Gill, were merely supporting actors in his solo tour de force. Every time New Jersey threatened to close the gap, Miller would answer with another improbable shot, silencing the run and extinguishing hope.

In the end, the final score was a mere footnote. The real story was the number 56, a career-high and franchise-record total that echoed through the arena. On this night, Reggie Miller wasn't just a star; he was a force of nature, delivering a performance for the ages that cemented his status as one of the game's most cold-blooded and iconic scorers.
